content.title: Merville Maze, a cultural escape game

introduction.small: Visitors of all ages will love the myriad of puzzles and thrilling challenges to solve at Melville Castle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Merville Maze, a cultural escape game

paragraphs.text:
Around 20km from Toulouse, Merville Castle - a superb pink brick building dating back to the early 18th century - towers over the surrounding area. However interesting the building may be, the main attraction is out in the gardens, where pathways lined with vast box hedges cover almost six kilometres of the grounds. Slip inside these green passageways and lose yourself in the biggest boxwood maze in Europe…

In this veritable outdoor escape game, walkers are asked to solve mysteries and complete challenges as they follow one of two routes. The first is “Enigma”, which is themed around inventions and key figures in the history of science like Marie Curie, Leonardo da Vinci, Galileo and even Bill Gates. Here, you will need to solve puzzles to get past obstacles, water doors and gates, and crack the code to escape the maze.

The other route is “Dédale”, which will take you on a wonderful wander peppered with historical anecdotes about the castle and grounds. Using a combination of a mobile app downloaded on your smartphone and nine interactive terminals along the route, you will get to travel through 250 years of the estate's history, from when it was built by the Marquis de Chalvet and Seneschal of Toulouse until it was handed down to the Marquis de Beaumont du Repaire, the ancestor of the current owners.

During one unforgettable afternoon, the whole family can go back in time and discover the many different histories to this unique place.

content.title: On a culinary journey at Nomades

introduction.small: Come and share your love of journeying in the very heart of Toulouse, on a sun-drenched terrace facing the Saint-Étienne cathedral.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On a culinary journey at Nomades

paragraphs.text:
The lovely red front is a perfect match for the city's brick buildings. Entering Nomades in the historic centre of Toulouse is a little bit like reconnecting with a spirit of exploration and liberty left aside for too long in daily life. Decoration is stripped-down and strikes a balance in which the essential is enough.

For your gustatory enjoyment, the owners Arnaud, Sylvain and Valentin offer you a tasty menu full of flavours inspired by their own experiences across the world, but using only fresh, local and seasonal products. Here, these three travelling enthusiasts revisit the recipes of chef and globetrotter Patrick Brandao. Dishes are authentic and straightforward, as every mouthful of your beef bourguignon tacos with a wine and mustard sauce, or pollock ceviche with sweet potatoes, grilled corn, coconut and wasabi foam, and prickly pear and pomegranate dressing will attest. For curious patrons who welcome some guidance, a unique menu is served every night. You got it right, the atmosphere is definitely special. So be ready to embark on a culinary journey at the table and marvel, as a bonus, at the wonderful view over the Saint-Étienne cathedral..

content.title: Grand cru wines in self-service at 5 Wine Bar

introduction.small: Three times wine bar world champion, 5 Wine Bar stands out from all others in Toulouse with its Grand cru self-service concept.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand cru wines in self-service at 5 Wine Bar

paragraphs.text:
It is the pride and joy of Toulouse and even the entire region. Crowned best wine bar in the world on multiple occasions by the major British magazine The World of Fine Wine, 5 Wine Bar is the only establishment of its kind to have been awarded three years in a row. With over 4,000 references, including 500 by the glass, all wine-producing regions on the globe are present, even though the Toulouse bar remains a strong proponent of local wines, offering various selections by the glass at a low price (to be enjoyed in moderation of course).

Far removed from traditional wine bars, the success of 5 Wine Bar largely holds due to its Grand cru self-service concept. Wine and champagne lovers can fill their glasses directly, depending on their thirst (1.5cl, 4.5cl or 10cl). In the lobby, you simply need to insert a card as if you were at an ATM, and then serve yourself. Rest assured, you are in good hands as seasoned sommeliers are available to guide your choice. Kitchen-side, wines can be accompanied by a few tapas also from small local producers.

content.title: Bistroquet à la une, three-in-one

On the other, the canteen and its lovely dishes in a small plate (those XS-type dishes that come one after the other) allowing your party to share (or not, depending on everyone's hunger) various flavours in one meal.

Everything here is made with fresh ingredients, and recipes change according to the seasons. Baked camembert, shredded duck with chimichurri, foie gras mi-cuit with toast… it makes it so hard to choose! Unless you opt for one of their delicious prime ribs, aged for a minimum of 35 days. And on Sundays, it is brunch time at the canteen!

These two very distinctive styles come together at Bistroquet à la une, and they even blend at night into a welcoming and friendly tapas bar.

content.title: Mama Shelter on Toulouse time

introduction.small: Mama Shelter has settled into a new location in the heart of Toulouse near the Pierre Goudouli garden, and is paying tribute to the pink city at every opportunity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mama Shelter on Toulouse time

paragraphs.text:
With Mama Shelter's distinctive candy pink and raspberry frontage, you would be hard-pressed not to notice the stylish, trendy hotel chain's new home in Toulouse. Away from the hustle and bustle of the city centre, but still just a ten-minute walk to the Capitole, the hotel has become part of the fabric of local life. Look up as you step inside to see a work of art by Beni Lloyds bright against the black chalkboard ceiling of its bar and restaurant. It pays homage to life in Toulouse, and there is plenty of fun to be had spotting words in Occitan, references to the Garonne, and lyrics from songs by Claude Nougaro. The building itself is one of the former cinemas so typical of the area, and it too has been celebrated by its new occupant with CinéMama, a private space reserved for hotel and restaurant guests. As one last tribute to Toulouse, there is the rooftop bar: head up at sunset and you will find not only a pizza oven and cart filled with homemade ice creams and sorbets, but also unrivalled views of the pink city ablaze in the day's last rays of sunshine.

content.title: Hôtel des Beaux Arts, character and eclecticism

introduction.small: In Toulouse, this boutique hotel offers rooms with distinct universes, but also unobstructed views over the Garonne River and the city's historic centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel des Beaux Arts, character and eclecticism

paragraphs.text:
It would be hard to find a better location in Toulouse: two steps away from the Pont-Neuf bridge in the Carmes neighbourhood, the Hôtel des Beaux Arts is housed in an 18th-century building, which is also a listed monument. The 18 pleasant rooms offer picture-postcard views of either the Garonne River or the city's historic centre. Each is practically a work of art in itself, right down to the layout, with a unique theme to every one: "Icons", elegant in its sobriety, displays black and white portraits of David Bowie, Serge Gainsbourg and Catherine Deneuve. The "Maye" room was named after a street artist from Montpellier and, as the name suggests, "Tribute to Mondrian" bears the mark of famous early 20th-century Dutch painter and pioneer of Abstract art Piet Mondrian. Often decorated by upcoming artists, the rooms display various original art pieces. Bargain-hunt from your bed - who knows, you may make an impulse buy!

district, the cultural site gathers three structures in one place: the modern art museum, centre for contemporary art, and the region's public collection of contemporary art. Opened in 2000, Les Abattoirs houses works of 20th-century artists all through today. The collection has been gradually enriched and expanded by donations from private collections (notably Anthony and Celia Denney), as well as Centre Pompidou.

La Voile Blanche is the address where you should spend your evenings to satisfy your desire to go out. In a party atmosphere around the pool, start off with dinner at the La Cantine 26 restaurant. The decor is very modern, with black leather benches and dark tones on the walls. Choose an assortment of tapas to share - deep-fried calamari with house-made aioli, sweet potato churros, or prawns wrapped in potato strings with a Thai sauce- or indulge in something from the excellent menu: the octopus platter served with ratatouille and chorizo, and the beef carpaccio with pesto and pine nuts are both wonderful choices. Carry on with an impressive grilled duck breast served in cep mushroom cream and with homemade fries, or the grilled king prawns in garlic and herbs with smashed potatoes. For dessert, do not miss the strawberry, mint and basil gazpacho with vanilla ice cream, or the raspberry and pistachio Charlotte Russe cake.

Events are regularly organised, such as Latin and reggae parties, pool parties, etc. You will certainly have a great time at La Voile Blanche, in a relaxed and warm atmosphere.

content.title: Following the story of woad

introduction.small: Known worldwide, the famous blue dye that reached its heyday in the Renaissance was born on the banks of the Garonne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Following the story of woad

paragraphs.text:
Unlike the pink colours of the city, this characteristic blue dye issues from a plant called isatis tinctoria, and more commonly known as woad. This plant used in the maceration of the dye was renowned in the Toulouse region in the Renaissance.

The harvest of the leaves, and the elaboration of the dye result in balls or shells called cocagnes, from which the dye is extracted. This is the origin of the expression 'Land of Cockaigne', which came to mean 'land of plenty'. The Toulouse traders became considerably richer as blue became increasingly fashionable in the 15th century. So today you can enjoy the magnificent mansions built in the city at that time, and which now appear with their beautiful… pink facades.

Push open the door of La Fleurée de Pastel, a small boutique with old-world charm that features dyed creations based on natural colours, such as silks or cottons with deep and authentic blues, but also beautiful soaps.

content.title: Le Bibent: an emblematic Toulouse restaurant

introduction.small: This Toulouse institution is a great place to enjoy some classic Toulouse cuisine, complete with views of the Capitol.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bibent: an emblematic Toulouse restaurant

paragraphs.text:
Do not hesitate to push open the door of this bright and welcoming Art Deco bistro, which opened for the first time in the late 19thcentury. Today, Yann Ghazal manages this famous Toulouse landmark, open seven days a week. The interior is a whirl of panelling, stucco mouldings, mosaics, and other Baroque follies that give the restaurant the dimensions of an old brasserie, but with a true bistro style.

In the kitchen, the classics revisited by the chef will not disappoint: a ginger-spiced oyster, bass and salmon tartare, bream tartare, beef and marrow-stuffed potatoes, guinea fowl supreme with fresh cheese, garlic and herbs, and Joël Robuchon's signature potato purée.. To celebrate the end of a delicious meal, go for the strawberries in vanilla oil, whipped fresh cream and rhubarb sorbet, or the raspberry, pistachio and orange blossom tart.
A menu drawn between the old and the new, and a succession of delights and pleasures. A cheerful experience, full of light.

Both indoor and outdoor, the restaurant, located in the hotel's courtyard, will delight foodies with its gastronomic and modern cuisine. content.title: The Chasselas de Moissac grape: a fruit of great character

introduction.small: You can find this delicious white grape with a thousand virtues just outside of Toulouse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Chasselas de Moissac grape: a fruit of great character

The climate of the valley allows the culture of many fruits, including that of the famous Chasselas de Moissac grape, which has made the reputation of the city. Come taste it in its myriad forms and discover its highly detoxifying properties. Its consumption helps to purify the body and to rapidly regenerate cells, so the Chasselas course of treatment is a classic in the region. During your time in the medieval city, you can also visit the Saint-Pierre Abbey and adjoining cloisters, masterpieces of Roman art that have been listed as UNESCO World Heritage sites.

While you are there, book a table at M. 1474, the restaurant at the Le Moulin de Moissac hotel, for a gourmet fine-dining experience. The splendid views of the surrounding countryside and the bucolic banks of the Tarn are an additional attraction.

content.title: Toulouse gastronomy: a discovery in good taste

introduction.small: The discovery of gourmet specialities from the south-west is a necessity in Toulouse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Toulouse gastronomy: a discovery in good taste

paragraphs.text:
You cannot stay in Toulouse without tasting the iconic cassoulet, a typical dish of the region, which has been the source of several quarrels between the cities of Toulouse, Carcassonne, and Castelnaudary, who all claim its invention.

It is a dish comprised of the white beans of Tarbes and of Toulouse sausage, and is eaten throughout the year in the pink city. The Maison Garcia has held the reputation as the city's best butcher for a long time and is a must visit on your gourmet walk. You will find, of course, the Toulouse sausage, but also other excellent meat sausages. To end on a sweet note, discover the local apple crisp, a puff pastry made with Armagnac-scented fruit. The Sandyan pastry shop is apt to assuage all your cravings for sweets.

Finish with a taste of violets, another Toulouse speciality, by trying a delicious sorbet made with the aromas of the little flower that once made the fame of the city at Philippe Faur, the ice cream maker you will find inside Le Florida café.

The legendary Toulouse team, Stade Toulousain, has enabled the city to acquire worldwide fame in sports. The greatest rugby players in the world come to live in the pink city to practice this legendary game. Toulouse's game philosophy is well-known worldwide, all the way to the shores of New Zealand: home to the All Blacks.

Rugby arrived in the region in the 19th century and was first played in the city's universities. The traditional team colours are red and black, in memory of the former capitouls, or sheriffs, who were municipal councillors.

During your stay in Toulouse, and depending on the season, be sure to attend a match at the stadium to watch this legendary team play. Take advantage of the 'third half' and head to the Rouge et Noir, the official supporters' bar with unique decoration that pays tribute to the local club. Spending some time with the friendly fans of this iconic sport is guaranteed to be a welcoming experience - supercharged!

content.title: Toulouse by water

introduction.small: Embark on an unusual tour of the city via its waterways.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Toulouse by water

paragraphs.text:
Toulouse is located on the banks of the Garonne and the Canal du Midi, with a range of cruises to choose from for a tranquil few hours' sailing through the Pink City.

This is a delightful experience, especially in summer, allowing you to admire the monuments and bridges of the city from another perspective. The barge cruises take you where you choose, on the Garonne around central Toulouse, or the Canal du Midi and the Canal de Brienne outside the city. For those who wish, small boats may be rented for limited use.

The Canal du Midi is a marvel of ingenuity and a complete change of scene with the romance of its green banks. Strolling under the majestic tall trees that border the canal is also not to be missed. Built in the 17th century, the canal connects the Garonne River to the Mediterranean and thus allows a river link from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean.

content.title: Spend a night in the trees

In the middle of the Quercy Valley, less than an hour from Toulouse, the Domaine de la Male welcomes you for an unforgettable stay in one of its cabins, which have been built on stilts high among the trees. A gourmet basket will be delivered by pulley for your dinner, should you so wish, allowing you to live a treetop dream amid the oaks. The domain can also enlighten those who wish to learn more about the riches of nature in the south-west.

content.title: The mansions of Toulouse: architectural gems

introduction.small: Stroll the streets of Toulouse and discover the Pink City's stunning mansions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The mansions of Toulouse: architectural gems

paragraphs.text:
Toulouse's emblematic hôtels particuliers (mansions), previously owned by the nobility or rich pastel merchants, may be visited during your walks in the city centre.

The famous Hôtel d'Assézat opens its doors not far from the Place Esquirol. This splendid house in a typical Renaissance style was built by the most sought-after architect of the 16th century, Nicolas Bachelier. While admiring the mansion's inner courtyard, you might note that it is almost a replica of the Cour Carrée of the Louvre. The Bemberg Foundation, now a museum that brings together an impressive collection of paintings, may also be visited. Carrying on, Antoine Dumay, a doctor renowned for having treated Queen Margot - the first wife of King Henry IV - built the Dumay Mansion in the 16th century.

Our next stop is the Hôtel Jean de Bagis, a magnificent example of the Toulouse Renaissance. Built for a wealthy chairman of the parliament of Toulouse, this mansion has the nickname of 'the stone mansion' because its facade is one of the few examples of stone (not brick) construction in the city.

content.title: Michel Sarran: the gastronomic exception

introduction.small: Enjoy top-flight cuisine celebrating both the land and sea in warm, welcoming surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Michel Sarran: the gastronomic exception

paragraphs.text:
Indulge yourself by booking a table with this extraordinary chef, who arrived in Toulouse in 1995 and is very much leaving his mark on the city. At Michel Sarran, dining is not taken lightly. 'We are merchants of pleasure', announces the Michelin-starred chef proudly.
Everything breathes the art of living and generosity in this restaurant, with its tasteful and warm decoration. In the kitchen, the spirit of 'home' dominates the dishes: recipes combine modernity and traditions, a remarkable union that will surprise your taste buds.

Start with a blanquette of frogs legs with basil served on a flaky mushroom and chorizo galette, followed by bass in a seaweed and dashi broth with three-cornered brown shrimp and preserved rhubarb ravioli if you are a fan of fish. Alternatively, there is the warm duck foie gras soup with Belon oyster, and the Mont Royal pigeon served with fennel, purple artichokes and black garlic, a parsley crumb and Kalamata olive jus.

If you have a sweet tooth, the desserts make the aromas sing: a chocolate disc with Gers walnuts on a dacquoise with cocoa sorbet and walnut oil snow, a croustade filled with apples flambeed in Armagnac and a Baked Alaska with orange liqueur, or a fresh peach poached in red wine with tarragon sorbet will make your mouth water: prepare for pleasure that you will not be able to resist.

content.title: Discovering Toulouse's Capitole

introduction.small: Dive into the history of the pink city by visiting the Capitol.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discovering Toulouse's Capitole

paragraphs.text:
The Capitol, the city's main square, is a jewel of neoclassical art of the 17th century, with its pink bricks and majestic facades.

It has been the emblem of the city since it was built more than eight centuries ago, and remains the seat of municipal power: the arts are also represented by a theatre. Its construction was decided in the very heyday of the city in the 12th century, but you can also admire the facades dating from the 17th. Look down when in the middle of the 12,000-sqm square and observe the beautiful Languedoc cross, the emblem of the city and the work of the artist Raymond Moretti.

Inside the theatre, there is a monumental staircase offering access to the floors, decorated with impressive frescoes depicting the history of the city. The city hall offers a tourist train for discovering the city's monuments in another light, including the Capitol.

content.title: Albi: the beautiful rival

introduction.small: Not far from Toulouse is Albi, a city that boasts surprising colours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Albi: the beautiful rival

paragraphs.text:
Once you arrive in Albi, around an hour's drive from Toulouse, the first thing that will impress you is the immense red-brick Saint Cecilia Cathedral: the only church built on this scale with this material in the world. Constructed in the 13th century, its 135m give it the appearance of a fortified castle (which it was originally).

Just next door, you can push open the heavy doors of the Berbie Palace, the dashingly beautiful former Episcopal Palace, which now houses the Toulouse-Lautrec Museum. Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, born in Albi, was the direct descendant of the Counts of Toulouse and was raised here. Aristocratic, whimsical, and small in stature due to a genetic disease, the painter made this last quality an asset. After his death (at age 37), his family bequeathed many paintings to his hometown, including his various portraits of artist Yvette Guilbert.

While you are here, we suggest you try the delicious recipes of L'Épicurien, one of Albi's finest tables, which features its own organic bread, fresh seasonal ingredients, and a savvy, well-conceived menu.

content.title: Le Saint-Sernin, a charming nest

introduction.small: Across from the splendid basilica of Saint-Sernin, this intimate and personalised hotel assures a restful stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Saint-Sernin, a charming nest

paragraphs.text:
If your prime concern is calm and tranquillity, this small hotel renovated on multiple counts since it opened in 1948 and with only 17 rooms is the perfect companion.

The carefully designed, classic decor referencing the rich artistic Occitan culture of Medieval times in muted tones adorns this establishment, which is situated in the city centre. An ideal location, only a stone's throw from lively areas filled with bars and restaurants by the Place du Capitole, that remains calm at night, for your sleeping enjoyment. All rooms are customised and some even offer great views of the 11th-century basilica of Saint-Sernin.

In summer, the greenery that is so abundant outside your bedroom window is a delight. The small seating area on the ground floor is a fine spot to quietly sit and enjoy this friendly place, where attentive service seems to be the trademark.
